The only "touch" button is the fingerprint sensor and the touch pad. The onboard graphics are as good as discrete graphics from a few years ago according to benchmarks, which is impressive. The speakers work well. Being an educator, I purchased it on the Apple Education Store for $1200, and it couldn't have come at a better time, given the transition to Zoom in the coronavirus pandemic. Thank you, Apple, for rediscovering yourself. I had been holding onto my 2012 MacBook Pro because I was unimpressed with the offerings the past few years.You shouldn't get this if you are looking for onboard power, but if you are, you probably didn't need me to tell you that. Otherwise, get it. It's great.

The keys are nice and smooth and the screen it bright. It holds a nice charge, especially when I play the sims with a pretty bright screen. I'm a computer technician and I'm also an author (ghost writer technically, so nothing is actually published in my name).  As a computer technician I would give this computer a 1/5.  It's a disposable paper bag with a horrible cooling system.  If one minor thing goes wrong with it, it's toast.  Soldered on SSD and RAM, very few modular components, etc.  So why did I buy it?Well, as an author I need a computer with a good keyboard that's lightweight and has a long battery life.  For writing and reading articles online, this computer is great.  If you need to do ANYTHING else however (including watching YouTube videos - which wouldn't be taxing on any other computer), you should choose a different computer.  The cooling system I mentioned?  It's basically non-existent.  The fan isn't connected to the heat sink at all.  This means that if you use the computer for anything taxing at all (YouTube videos, games, photo editing, etc.) it's going to overheat.  This will cause the computer to die in about a year or two, and when it does, the cost for repair is going to be close to $1,000 because of the way Apple designed it.

The camera has a poor image quality (only 720p) and the fan gets very loud during FaceTime/Zoom calls. The MacBook Air 2020, like the MacBook Air 2018 and 2019, has very poor thermal design because there is no pipe to connect the fan to the CPU's heatsink.The MacBook Air 2020 is suitable for causal use. But even a video call will push the CPU's temperature to a 100 degrees celsius. Because of the poor thermal design, the fan becomes loud and the device will thermal throttle (meaning it limits the CPU's speed in order to reduce its temperature). This was not a present problem in MacBook Air devices produced before 2018 as the CPUs in those devices were properly cooled (the fan was connected to the CPU with a pipe).
This MacBook Air is extremely slow. Right out the box it was slow and even after updating it is still slow and seems to only be getting slower day by day. Returning. Avoid this rip-ff at all cost.

I ordered my MacBook Air from Apple within an hour of its announcement and have been enjoying it for a few days. I'm upgrading from a 2018 retina MacBook Air, and the 2020 model is a very worthwhile upgrade for a few reasons.First, the new keyboard really lives up to the hype.  I didn't hate the butterfly keyboard, but I didn't like typing on it nearly as much as the scissor-mechanism keyboards of the older MacBook Airs and pre-2016 MacBook pros.  Plus, I've had two machines with the butterfly keyboard (the other was the 2016 MB Pro with Touch Bar, that my employer provided me to use at work).  Both had problems with repeating keys, and in the case of Pro I use at work, some key presses randomly triggered some of the Touch Bar functions.

I ordered  a silver but got gold color!Specs are the same as I had requested though. Given current circumstances.. where I need a laptop badly to work from home...I don’t have a choice but to accept it.

Came in sealed. Easy to set-up. The screen is beautiful. The Magic Keyboard feels very nice and a definite upgrade from the previous butterfly mechanism. The camera quality is just what I need. If you are going to be at school or at work doing zoom calls with other people, they can see you clearly. The camera, in my opinion, could definitely be improved, especially because of that high price. That seems to be the only “flaw.” Lastly, I will talk about the fan noise and the MacBook “heating up.” In my personal use, the MacBook never heated up (even on the bottom) and the fan was only heard just a bit when I was downloading a large app file. From day-to-day use of browsing, Netflix, zoom calls, and presentations, you would most likely never hear the fan nor feel the heat from underneath your keyboard. I’d definitely recommend this computer, especially if it’s your first Mac. Enjoy!Update: After less than a week of purchasing, this MacBook still works fantastic. However, once I started up Minecraft and played creative for just 2 minutes, the fan started blasting and was very loud. I do not suggest this computer if you want to game, however, for daily usage, it's wonderful.

Other than that. It’s a nice laptop and worth the extra $49 amazon charges over apple for the faster delivery.I will update my review once I start using my MacBook more.

So far it’s been a killer of a laptop! The keyboard is pretty great and it sounds and feels great to type on. I actually want to write with my laptop now. I got the i3 model, and as it doesn’t sound impressive I think it’s the best option for the MacBook Air as this laptop does have overheating issues (hence the 4/5 stars) and as the i3 doesn’t require as much power as an i5 or i7, it doesn’t have as bad of throttling issues. It remains fast enough for my needs as well, it also has enough storage for my 25GB of music, my entire 20GB of google drive and all my apps, and it runs them all pretty fast, including Adobe Lightroom.TLDR: A fast little laptop with great build and aesthetic, improved keyboard, great speakers (for a laptop), and a lower than average MacBook price. I returned that Air, and replaced it with the 500+GB SSD and quad core processor. Wow! The difference in performance is marked! The onboard speaker won't ever be confused for an external sound system, but it is the best onboard speaker system I've heard. The Retina screen looks great; vibrant and detailed. I also love the large touch pad with the gestures.

Long review BUT worth the read...After looking at numerous reviews about the MBA 2020 and the MBP 2020...I decided on the MBA and I'm so glad I did!!! I had an early-release MBA 2010 which I loved (...and lasted perfectly until 2016 despite having a cracked plastic hard-shell, it was the base model too)...I decided to pick-up a MBP 2015 which was great at the time due to me doing a lot of video editing because my old MBA could do it BUT it took forever. My MBP 2015 still works fine BUT occasionally experience glitches and I realized it would be smart to get another Macbook especially since I'm working from home everyday during these covid-19 times.

I have owned iPods & iPads over the years but never had the money to purchase a Mac until now. I am so glad I did. This was a big purchase for me, I have never spent more than $300 on a laptop, I don't even own a RTX 2080 in my gaming PC. I work in IT and I felt not knowing much about Mac OS was sort of hindering me, so I just decided to spend the money and get myself a Mac to get acquainted with the operating system. I went with the base version (i3, 8GB RAM) and so far I have not noticed anything wrong with the performance. I am not a power user as far as editing video / photos by no means, but I'm sure this MacBook can handle it without an issue. My tasks include web browsing, email, music, electronic banking, and working on documents amongst a few other basic tasks. At first I felt like throwing down $900 on a MacBook just for these tasks was going to be a waste and a big time impulse buy, but I feel it will definitely come in handy. The color is amazing, I am so used to seeing the typical silver MacBook, but space gray is the best option IMO. It's super lightweight, the retina display is crisp & beautiful, the battery lasts a very long time, speakers are loud and clear, and the keyboard just feels so nice! The trackpad is really nice too with its many useful gestures. It does get slightly warm during extended use but that's to be expected since there's no vents for ventilation. I wish it had more IO like at least one USB A port, but nothing a hub can't fix. Also, I wish the components were upgradable like the RAM & SSD. 8GB RAM is definitely enough more than enough for basic day to day tasks. MacOS is super easy to navigate and everything just works. I will admit it takes a few more steps to get software installed, the OS is very restricted and requires admin privileges for almost anything, but it makes me feel secure. Touch ID is very nice and works flawlessly. I did install trend micro and Malwarebytes for security just to give myself some insurance on being secure. Having used Windows for many years, there are a few things that I need to remember works differently on Mac. All in all, a really great purchase, Apple definitely knocks out of the ballpark when it comes to quality, everything looks and feels premium.

I bought mine on another website because Amazon didn't offer the configuration I wanted, which was 1.1 GHz 10th-generation i5 with 16 GB of RAM.  This laptop is absolutely beautiful.  The keyboard is fantastic improvement (I have a 12" Macbook with the butterfly keys, and it's a horrible design with no key travel).  The Retina screen is gorgeous.  It's quick and responsive, and I love the new touch login button.  Like most Apple products, build quality is stellar.However, it runs quite warm.  Installed an app called "Monity" which shows CPU temperature among other sensor information.  It's not uncommon for the CPU in this version under normal browsing - not a heavy load - to run between 160 and 185F, which is 85C.  Much warmer - 20 or 30 degrees - than the 2.7 GHz i5 in my 2015 Macbook Pro sitting right next to it with similar use.  The numbers alone are one thing, but this laptop is uncomfortable to surf with while on in your lap. You can feel the heat emanating from the bottom under light use.  There are lots of forums with debates as to whether the i3 might be a better choice as some users say it runs cooler, which makes sense as it only has two cores and draws less power, though I haven't experienced it.  The i5 seems like a good performer, but this Macbook Air is noticeably warmer - uncomfortably so -  than the 2017 and earlier design of Air that I used to have.  Operating it on a surface, though, and not your lap is fine.  I have read that the new design does not have a a heat pipe from the CPU to the cooling fan, which seems like a strange change.
